element_texts.text:
April 2nd '39
119th Day C N G Strike
Dear Nelson:
I'm sorry I had to miss the Anvil brawl but my sobriety and insolvency plus prospect of working today kept me near my bed on the old back porch.
I liked the New Anvil.  Read every word.  As I am not established as a Morton Zabel nor Hazlitt I won't bore you with any preferences of mine - but in answer to your inquiry:
"Who will play Lenin to Chicago"?
Permit me to suggest the name:
Edward J Kelly!
It was good to hear about Lawrence O'Fallon.  I'm writing him after finishing this short note.  We serfs have tried to go along more or less constitutionally without a constitution (A la IWW in '18) - so it's hard to tell people just how we may be formed.  However I'll write O'Fallon of what we have done and make a few suggestions about what he can do in his "diocese."
J Norman Schmidt should be home soon.  We'll visit you together for an evening of bulling.
All the Best, Nelson -
J Cavanagh Diggles
Serf, Rtd (A F of L).

Feb 19th '44
Saturday
Dear Reverend "Toots":
Your latest letter to me in which you interpreted my 17 days of pain (?) in the Post Hospital as a modern archtype (sic) of St Alphonsus' sufferings - is -, I fear, a flattering interpretation of events.  I fear there was more "virus" than virtue in the whole business.
Jack - you'll note I have a new address.  "A-54" in place of "B-56".  It means only that I lost too much time in the hospital to stay with my own gang and wont be out of this camp until April 15th instead of March 15.  Since none of us know where we'll be after Callan I can't see that it makes much difference.
There was a rumor that out outfit was going to go from here to Ft. Bliss, Texas.  Bearing in mind Dr. Algren's remarks on that sovereign state I'm just as glad to put off such a fate for another month - and thus maybe avoid it all together.
I don't doubt you saw the enclosed article about Mrs. Shaw's will - and read it with mixed emotions.  Mary sent ti to me - and off-hand I have 2 thoughts on the subject:

2.
I. The sum is entirely inadequate for the huge objective aimed at - tho a move in the right direction.
II.   When G.B.S. dies he should leave $1,200,000.00 to civilize the English.
With them and the Gaels civilized I'm sure the Scotch and the Welsh would be a minor problem.
It is good to hear you are still a "Dad's" dad.  Bearing in mind the terrific upset of the Forhaus you should go to "A.A." at least occasionally - and go with Ken Garner who needs both "AA" and Gaelic companionship - Mrs. G.B.S. notwithstanding.
The enclosed 3 prayers are for you to say for us.  Mary had 'em put out at the Y.W.C.A.   Roman infiltration of the rankest sort!
Some nite call the Mrs.J - Chesapeake 1475 - and assure her that her distant spouse is
1  loving
2  faithful
3  sober!
Regards to Gladice and all the family - and to the "AA"s and the Rev. Burrell.
Write!
Fraternally,
Pvt. Joe Diggles

Image
Postcard of portrait of Brig. Gen Beauregard Lillard-Bond

[pencil notation in top margin]  Diggles, Joe
Brig. General
Beauregard Lillard Bond
(Confederate States of America)
1820-1880
- The Terror of the Mississippi Basin
Author of the aphorism
"Peace - it's hell"
from ex-Pfc Admirer
J.C. Diggles '44

letterhead  U.S. Army  Camp Callan   San Diego, California

March 17, 1944.
St Patrick's Day.
Dear Rev. C:
All Gaelic Greetings of the Day!
The enclosed clipping about the Battery Clerk of "A-52" I felt sure would thrill you.  It is indicative of the high moral tone in the Army as seen in Camp Callan - and a fine rebuttal to "Lost Week End" and the book you reviewed in the "Sun" about the rum-ridden furlough of some Navy men.
A typed letter from the Rev. B. brought the news he is still boozing - a fact which we must work against.  I herewith appoint you as my Proxy Crusader.
Burrell is having the "horrors", Jack.  In his epistle he conjured up a vision of you having several beers with some dame and reciting to her "The Coach Up ahead."  Poor Burrell!  He seems to think that this weird and unseemly phantasm had a basis in fact.  For the sake of all "AA",

2
Reverend, you'd better scotch these dire slanders.
I heard from Ken Garner.  I believe he is back on the beam.  I'm still waiting to hear from you or him what you did about the rebuff he suffered at the hands of Down-town AA.
I'm reading "Good Night, Sweet Prince" - and it is good fun.  My enjoyment of "Lost Week End" was great.  From hence forward, Rev. - let us keep our binges in literature.
Write soon, Jack - and tell me of your success (or lack thereof) against the Bottle.
- fraternally,
PVT. J.C.D.

June 7, 1944
Dear reverend C.
It may be a hellish thing to do, but I have taken to making my friends a target for my typing practice.  Like Hamlets father I find ye letters leaving the military world with all its errors on its noggin.
The main temperature here is usually too high but in spite of my many afflictions I am writing to thank you for the flatteringly-inscribed "anthology" and to assure you I will enjoy it as soon as I finish "famine" which I am now reading.  I should be reading "Clausewitz" but I prefer Oflaherty.
Some time ago I sendt [sic] the recverend [sic] Burrell 2 American dollars with which to buy some root-beer and to call on you for a "quiet time" in my memory preparatory to Burrell taking the pledge again for life.
I must grant that the odds against the reverend at this time are rather high but if the miracle does occur and the great light shines on the prodigal of Oakland then you and I can each take credit for 50 percent of a miracle.
It is only real fair to the grateful taxpayers to tell them if they inquire that Pvt. D is still sober and still a long way fron [sic] big time as soldier.  Maybe I will become more furious and efficient after a year of this existence.  the 13th of this month I will be 37 and 7 months in the Army.  June 10th will be 20 months in AA (Schism).
Do write, Jack, and tell me your score in your endeavors - Christian and otherwise.  I trust you are still the only guy on 39th street who doesnt [sic] frequent such spots as "Ma and Pas".
Please give myj (sic) love to all the Conroys - and to Mary by phoning her and telling her to keep the Faith and practice the 12 steps.
How goes your book on Negro Migratiom [sic]?  I mustown [sic] a copy when it comes out and I will pay forit [sic] but the autograph will be on the house.
Thanks again, Jack.
Fraternally,
Joseph "Cokey" Diggles
P.S. Mary's phone is Chesapeake 1475.  She is thinking of attending the UofC in the fall - and I'd thank you for encouraging her to do so.  I'm doing the same - and 2 Revs are better than one! - JCO.

1
AAA -> AA (Abroad)
+
11 March 1945
4th Sunday in Lent
Somewhere in France
Dear Rev. "Toots":
Proletarian and non-alcoholic greetings from your fellow member of AA (Schism).  Jack, as of 10 March this soldat est 29 months on the wagon and ready to join you and Burrell and Co. in the formidable but joyous task of sobering up Cook County when the war ends.
As my favorite novelist, book reviewer and amateur evangelist I am glad to tell you I am offered a chance to commit a book - and the requisite character to refrain from doing so.  Maybe after the war you and I can c-author an "AA (Schism)" bible in which we'll suggest the mad notion that God loves non-Caucasians as well as He does reformed white drunks like ourselves.  We can have it published by the Irish underground and smuggle it into America via CIO maritime unions!
I enclose a pretty picture of the Tri-Color and its great slogan of the Jacobins.  Said slogan hath a Renascence in ETO but not all on the Allied side are too enthused.
Remember your farcical notion of an AA Cathedral Window of the thirsty AA saint gazing aloft towards the vision of "Dad's old fashioned Root Beer" in the cloud?  In my tent are 2 flap

2
openings thus <- sky

                     <- cloth
                     <- sky

so that I and 13 other liberators see "AA" literally carved in canvas and in sky!  Surely a "Carnal" sign of some deep spiritual fact.
Is "Rev." Burrell still alive?  Are the Gunns still putting the baby asleep with sips of whiskey?
Mary tells me there is a Spectorsky-Conroy "break".  For the public's sake I hope it mends - and for your $ reasons too.
After 5 years of war the franc is at 10% of Dictionary Par.  If we animated ingredients do as well I believe we're to be congratulated.
Love to all tax-payers, Jack.  Do write - and give my love to Mary (ma Femme), Gladys and Margaret and Jack & Tommy -
Fraternally,
Joe Diggles

3
and shows that the 12 steps will work anywhere - even in ETO (Czechoslovakian Section).
Jack, when your new book is out send me an autographed copy pronto - and rest assured I'll pay thee via Mary via Max Siegel's bookstore (hello to Max).
When you get your new address write me from it.  I did enjoy your letter enormously - and sent it to Mary to enjoy and to place in our AA (Schism) archives.
Unless some conscientious Nazi about 8 years old plugs me for flirting with his 5-year old sister I should get out of ETO alive.  Whether I go to CBI, USA or stay here to occupy the HITLER-less Deutschland remains to be seen.
Please give my love to Gladys, Margie, Jack & Tommy - and plenty for yourself.  Do make Forhan's meeting some night - Fred is a good guy.  Go as our Ambassador - a great AA "Pincer" where AA Schism and AA Wilson meet!
If you see Mary or have a nickel to phone give her my love also.
Requests: 1 - Another Letter

                2 - Your new book

Fraternally,
Joe Diggles
"ETO - AA (Schism)"

[Image]
PR-3 - CHAPEL, PRINCETON UNIVERSITY, PRINCETON, N.J.

Dear Reverend C:
In their window they have Witherspoon, St. Francis, Erasmus, Cardinal Mercier - and others.
How about $100,000.00 to put Reverend St. Robert of Oakland District Burrell up there - clasping his Bible, Daily Worker and Pepsi Cola bottle?
ecclesiastically -
Reverend D.
Mr. Jacob Conroy
6012 So. Green St.
Chicago
Ill.

[Letterhead]
Nicotinic Nobodies
GENERAL OFFICES . 800 SOUTH HALSTED ST . CHICAGO, ILLINOIS
Sunday 27 March 1949
4th in Lent
Dear Rev. C: VIVA!
We of NN (all 8 of us) feel you should know that we're opening a wide and fanatical drive to save millions from the degenerative effects of tobacco.  We know you personally are free of this insidious habit - but you might save some of your kith and kin.  35 sheets of this paper = $1.00.
At a St. Patrick's Day come all ye I met a Mrs. Siegel (very nice person) - who is the former Betty Jaffe - a WPA writer from the old era.  When we found out we had the friendship of Reverend C in common we had a fine visit about you.  She was touched to know of your austerity program and how you, I and the Rev. B are always thought of in Oakland-Kenwood circles as "The Apostles of Temperance"!
Let us have the usual quiet time over the absent Rev. B. - who maintains a sinister & stoney [sic] silence in snow-swept California!
Yours for saving the WEST from the Redman's Revenge (the Weed) - and the Irish Curse (the Bottle) - evangelistic'ly
Rev. D.

May 16 1947
Friday
Dear Rev,. C: VIVA!
The slogan "Wine is a mocker" I recall headed one of your more touching tracts - in Red letters.
And here some WCTU female warrior carries our warfare right into sinful California.
Rev. Burrell - once our prodigal son is dry 20 months May 18.  He, Ken, Redmond and I spoke at downtown AA May 6.  All went well.  Garner is dry 3 years May 8 - while Ted Brown who ran you & him out of "Y" in late '43 is in Kawbabee State Hospital - an alcoholic.
How goes the struggle?  Any need of rejoining us?  OR are you "saved" by literature - and Algren>
- fraternally -
Joe Diggles

[Letterhead]
Nicotinic Nobodies
GENERAL OFFICES . 800 SOUTH HALSTED ST. . CHICAGO, ILLINOIS
Sunday Aug. 29 1949.
Dear Jack:
Yours of Aug 16 from Yaddo received Aug 27 when I got home yesterday.  Mary and I vacationed in Ohio and didn't have our mail forwarded.
I'm glad to hear you've given up the struggle to become a gentleman-drinker - a role for which I am sure you are unsuited.  I have been attending AA on Wednesday morns 10.30 to 12 noon at 51st & So Parkway - and occasionally at the same place Saturday morns 10.30 to 12.  I'll give you a ring soon and see if we can't make that Saturday meeting together.
I had never heard of Yaddo which I would have surmised was a variant of Judo - except a friend of mine, Jack Gibbons Morris was in town recently - and in a 6 hour flow of talk told me ha has a novel in

2
progress - and hopes to get into Yaddo via Ralph Bates.  "Mad" Morris is an aberrant genius who was once wrought up enough to slug a Bishop (a Canonical offense!) - but is now an ex-Catholic via his 3rd marriage to a Vassar Professor who was Norris before she became Morris.
Bro Algren writing "The Man With the Golden Arm" sort of proves the theory of the Lady editor of the Polish Catholic paper which charged he was a degenerate and a dope fiend!  He owned to being degenerate (who - since Adam - isn't?) (save 2) - but now it appears he's an expert on the Hypo.  Instead of the famous Sherlock Holmes "The needle, Watson" it'll be "The needle, Algren".
Yours 2514 days sober

- Joe Diggles

P.S. AA is till going - we are some 75,000 - over 150 in Ireland!
- Joe D

Sept 5 1949
Monday
Dear Jack:
In the Sept "Grapevine" the AA monthly magazine there is an article:
"Was Dr. Johnson an AA"?
To refresh your memory the great coffee-house gent lived 1709-1784.
In his "Meditations", April 20, 1764 Johnson himself says in Part.
"I have made no Reformation; I have lived totally useless, more addicted to wine and meat-----".
Two years later Boswell says of him "There was now a considerable difference in his way of living.  Having had an illness, in which he was advised to leave off wine, he had, from that period, continued to abstain from it, and drinks only water, or lemonade."
Thus 1766, Dr. Johnson being then 57.
He was on the beam in 1772.  Still OK in 1776 - when Boswell wrote of him "Finding him still persevering in his abstinence from wine, I ventured to speak to

(2)
him of it.  Johnson replied:
"Sir, I have no objection to a man's drinking wine, if he can do it in moderation.  I found myself apt to go to excess in it and I thought it better NOT to return to it.  Every man is to judge for himself, according to the effects which he experiences."
- "is not that pretty good AA FOR 1776?"
In 1781 (after 15 years wineless!) the good doctor seems to have had a bad slip, for Boswell asked him if it were true that he had lately returned to wine.  Johnson replied, "I drink it now sometimes, but not socially."
Then Boswell says, "He poured a large quantity of it into a glass, and swallowed it greedily.  Everything about his character and manners was forcible and violent; there never was any moderation.  Many a year did he drink wine; when he did drink wine, it was copiously.  He could practice abstinence, but not Temperance."
In his last 2 or 3

(3)
years the good doctor got back on the beam - even touring Scotland with Boswell without falling for the popular native drink - whiskey.
So much on DR. J --- R.I.P.
Bill Williams is just home from a 7000 mile tour (auto) of the West.  I am sad to report that Mrs. Burrell (Dr. Bob's ma) informed Bill during a cordial visit that Rev. B has been drunk lately - scorning the glorious orange-juice of sunny Cal. for the old yockey-Dock!
(Let us have the usual quiet time in his honor).
Hoping to see you as soon as convenient for you.
- Soberly & Sincerely -
Joe Diggles

[Newspaper clipping:]
The Sun Times 9/16/49
Arrest Priest after drug raid
Montreal (UP) -- A Catholic priest and a restaurant owner were arrested by Royal Canadian Mounted Police Thursday and charged with possessing $45,000 worth of narcotics.
Police arrested the Rev. Arthur Taillefer and Michael Sisco after raiding a locker in Windsor Station Wednesday.
Inspector J. Brunet said the raid uncovered 32 ounces of heroin which could have been divided into 15,000 capsules retialing at $3 each.
It was the biggest cache of heroin ever discovered in this area," Brunet said.
Father Taillefer and Sisco were to be arraigned on charges of illegal possession of narcotics.
Sept 16 '49
Dear Rev. C.
The next time the Polish Catholic newspaper calls Algren a "degenerate and dope fiend" make him show the editor this little item from beautiful Montreal.
This harrowing tale should help bury that ancient cheap gibe that "Religion is the opium of the People".  Clearly Rev. Taillefer needed something stronger and fiercely malevolent to be "The Priest with the Golden Arm".
OR was he - just a medical missionary - building up a bit of reserve?
Yrs minus all narcotics -
J.C.D.

Jan 19 '50
Thurs
Dear Jack:  We've other plans which won't re-arrange easily that will keep us away from your literary come-all-ye this Sat.
However I do want to be represented to the tune of $2.50 - not for the poetry (I only read meta-physical verse - e.g. Conroy, Coleridge, Joseph F. Gould) - but for any pamphlets on the horrors of drinking or smoking you may see fit to give out amongst the intellectuals present.
Here are some AA statistics from Ireland to gladden your heart:
Dublin groups - 140
Belfast - 30 to 40
Limerick - 5
Cork - 3
as of Jan 15, 1950.
Ireland's total AA - about 180.
Don't forget Feb 19 3PM - at our place.
And bring Gooch - and Rev. Algren - the reformed junker.
- fraternally -
Joe Diggles

[red pencil note above letterhead]
How about some NN recruits from Yaddo? - JCD
[Letterhead]
Nicotinic Nobodies
GENERAL OFFICES . 800 SOUTH HALSTED ST. . CHICAGO ILLINOIS
August 11 '50
Friday
Dear Jack:
Thanks for the Yaddo card - t adorn my RR Shanty Art Gallery.  It arrived with some of your tracts sent me by Tom and Zehava upon a telephone request by me.
We now have 15 NN - 13 in USA 2 in Ireland.  Former Mayor Kelly of Chicago joined.  I'll show you his letter of joyous acceptance.  Ed is 71.  Practic'ly a death-bed repentance!
I enclose one of the richest tracts - to show to any female intellectual who may be afflicted with the noisome habit.
I never hear from Rev. B.  Alas!  He must be deviating from the AA Party line.
Give us a ring when you're back in the Queen City of the Prairies.
- fraternally and reformationly -
Joe Diggles

[Letterhead]
Nicotinic Nobodies
GENERAL OFFICES . 800 SOUTH HALSTED ST. . CHICAGO ILLINOIS
August 11 '50
Dear Tom:  Thanks a million for the fine collection of tracts.
It saddened and shocked me to hear Zehava was in doubt as to my seriousness.  Alas!  Such is the Cross of every reformer, I suppose.
We of NN are now 15.  13 in America - 2 in Ireland.  Ex mayor Ed Kelly has joined at 71 - which goes to show it is never too late to repent as long as the respiratory organs are functioning.
I had a card from "Yaddo Daddo" Conroy.  I informed him of your fine co-operation in our endeavors.
Let us strive for - empty ash-trays all over the world!
- fanatic'ly
- Joe Diggles

[Letterhead]
Nicotinic Nobodies
GENERAL OFFICES . 800 SOUTH HALSTED ST. . CHICAGO ILLINOIS
Sept 6 '50
Wednesday
Dear Rev. C:
Note here a startling case of the ethical degeneration inevitable in nicotine addicts.
There are now regular meetings at Hull House for Junior Junkies - dope addicts between 15 and 21 years of age.  This is an effort to trans-plant AA amongst the needle-boys.  Whether it will succeed remains to be seen.  "Prognosis guarded."
You might tell Algren about it.  I still harbor the hunch that he is "hooked".  This is either a tribute to his literary powers on the subject - or a very unfair thought for me to harbor concerning n old neighbor.
Maye he'd like to be the Bill Wilson of Chicago's "Addicts Anonymous"!  ->

2
The majority of the Junior Junkies are Negro.  ON the North side the Lakeview high school produces the biggest Caucasian crop - just why I can't say.
Isn't it a shame we don't have the Rev. Robert Dowie Burrell in all this reform movement!  He walked the twilight world of addiction between the juice habit and the heroin kicks - the midway of the barbiturates.  And - o sad fact! - he smoked cigarettes also!
Let's have a call or a note from you.  Since you've gone "Yaddo" all the reform work has fallen on my frail shoulders.
Soberly -
Rev. D.
P.S. I enclose a remarkably sound booklet by a Catholic priest who knows about booze the hard way. - JCD

[Newspaper clipping:]
TARS FIND WAY TO BEAT DANISH COIN MACHINE
[Chicago Tribune Press Service]
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 3 - Tobacco dealers opening their cigaret [sic] machine are finding large quantities of English half pennies which, tho worth only one-tenth as much as the Danish crown, are exactly the same size and weight.  The dealers are complaining to the British embassy, pointing out that the British fleet has just paid Copenhagen a visit and sailors were noticed buying many cigarets [sic] from the machines.  The embassy, however, is referring complaints to the Danish police.

Dear Jack:
[Text from back of postcard:]
Pictured here is the parlor of General Grant's home just as he left it for the White House.  This home built in 1857 by Alexander Jackson, and presented to General Grant by the citizens of Galena in 1865 and later presented to the city by Grant's children in 1904, was made a State Memorial in 1932.

Back in those days there was no St. Joseph's Aspirin - nor AA.
It was tough!
- Joe Diggles
Rev. Jack "Toots" Conroy
Yaddo
Saratoga Springs
N.Y.

Sept 22 '50
Friday
Dear Jack: This item made me wonder if Rev. B isn't in TOWN - and about to enlist from "Ma and PA's"
I also enclose an article about the heinous role of the cigarette in domestic life - dug out of the "Tribune" by Francis Joseph Walsh - Pres. of NN.
Did you look for the needle marks in Algren's arm?
Soberly and smoke-lessly
- Joe Diggles
P.S. I saw the "Bulletin".  You're like Jane Addams - i.e. beloved in your old age!
- JCD

[Newspaper clipping applicable to previous page:]
He Wants His Beer to Fight
Give the G.I.s all the beer they want.  They're giving the country their lives.  All that the WCTU ever gave this country was trouble.
When I get back into uniform I want my beer.  And if I can't get it I'll want to know why doesn't the WCTU arm itself with umbrellas and soda pop and go fight for the country it wants to control.
Am I going to fight one form of totalitarianism only to find myself shackled under another dictatorship?
Chicago.  HERE'S TO YOU.

Dear Rev. C:  I was very intrigued to discover there actually is a Coldwater Mich!
When I get my R.R. Pension (1972) let us move there and devout [sic] our last years to AA and NN works.
- fervently
- Rev. D.
Rev. Jack "Toots" Conroy
6012 S. Green St.
Chicago

24 Nov, 1950
Friday
Dear Jack: I enclose a picture of the biggest fire that ever started in our neighborhood.  Would that our leaflets might so inflame unsaved smokers and boozers!
Alas!  John B. Gough - that soldier of the Lord is NOT in Webster's Biographical - but 2 other Goughs are - soldiers of that Profane Cause  - The British Empire!  It's pronounced "GoF."
Page 544 of Gough's auto-biography reads thus"
"From accurate accounts kept I find that from May 14, 1843 to June 1, 1869, I have delivered six thousand and sixty-four addresses and traveled two hundred and seventy two thousand two hundred and thirty-five miles, independent of all traveling for pleasure, or on occasions not connected with my work."
From these prodigious figures you can see what a task lies before me, your fellow-evangelist if I am to properly answer to the name "The Gough of Hull House."!
Of course brother Gough is speaking of a twenty-six year span (1843-1869).  I shan't be sober 26 years until Oct. 1968 - nor in AA 26 years until June 17, 1969.  The latter date

2
happens to be the centennial of the edition of Gough's autobiography which you gave me.
At that time (17 June 1969) let us meet together and put out a few hundred tracts on the Halsted St. streetcars in celebration of the great occasion.
I'll give you my travel-mileage then - and some statistics on tracts given away - a number which should be astronomical indeed!
Let us close this epistle with the usual quiet time for Reverend B - who may be playing hookey [sic] from the Lord's Vineyard at the moment.
fanatic'ly yours
- Rev. J. C. Diggles
Hull House

[Newspaper clipping:]
She Explored Belgian Congo
(Continued from Page 1, This Section)
cure more than 11,000 natives afterward.
Assisted by his present wife, Dr. Kellsberger later established a leprosarium (the first in the Belgian Congo) at Bibanga.  In fact, it was their teamwork there that led to their recall to this country 10 years ago and their appointment as general and promotion secretary, respectively, of the American Leprosy Mission.

* *
Discussing her life in the Congo while in town last week, Mrs. Kellersberger told how, when she first arrived, Americans and Europeans were so scare in Africa that the natives considered every white man a missionary.
On her first trip, she said, she and her husband traveled by river boat up the Congo for 1,000 miles to a native village where a Ford truck was waiting.  It carried them over roughly carved trails and across crocodile-infested rivers to Poonah, their mission station 600 miles farther inland.
"Whenever we came to a river on that journey," she continued, "bands of natives would be drawn up on the banks and their chiefs would greet us with: 'Go no farther, Man and Woman of God!  We will build you a church.  We will build you a school.  We will build you a house.'"

* *
But six years later, she added, when they retraced that trip after a sabbatical leave home, "the whole picture had changed."  During that interval, mining engineers, oil and tobacco men, gold prospectors and traders had split the jungle widen [sic] open.
"In one village where no white woman ever had been before," she went on, "I saw little children gambling with American dice.
Wherever I went on my first trip into Africa, the people greeted us with: 'Give us the palaver of God.'  But after our furlough home the same natives welcomed us with: 'Give me a cigaret!'"
Ch Sun Times
2/21/51
Dear Rev. "Toots":
This tale is a tremendous footnote to Spengler's "Decline of the West".
Rev. D..
What tobacco did to the white man it next shall do to the black!
Morose-ly
JCD.

[Newspaper clipping:]
And So Good Night.  In South Bend, Ind., a thief slugged the caretaker of a social club, lifted $1,850 from the safe, paused in his flight to put a pillow under the fallen watchman's head and give him a double shot of whisky from the club's supply.
"Time" 2/26/51
2/26/51
Dear Rev. C:
This item from the heart of America's football culture puts me in mind of the humanitarian who gave you beer out of the cat's plate while you were wedged under the seat in "Jolly John's" back in your un-regenerate days.
Some evenings ago I met Bill Kruck ("Little Nell") and his charming Finnish wife.  Hadn't seen him in a coon's age.  We had a fine evening - and some spring day will invade Dolvuer's Grove to see them in their house.
I am sorely in need of some NN tracts.  Can you send me some?  Saw our Holy (?) Founder. F. J. Walsh, last night.  He is firm in the NN Faith - and practice.
In 1935 Bill Kruck and I were both Delegates to a Peace Conference in Detroit.  I was a mere slip of a lad - aged 28.
Please send the NN tracts soon.
In the Vine-yard - but NOT full of Wine.
Joe D.

3/4/51
Dear Jack
Natchez, Miss.
Shall we buy "Nutt's Folly" and finish it and use it as our Southern Hdqtrs for NN leaflets?
Death to the tobacconists!
- fanatic'ly
- Joe D

[Newspaper clipping applicable to previous page:]
This octagonal Moorish castle was named Longwood, but is called "Nutt's Folly."  Conceived by Dr. Haller Nutt, it was still under construction when the Civil war began and it never was finished.

[Letterhead]
Hull House
800 SO. HALSTED STREET
CHICAGO 7, ILLINOIS
17 April 1951.
Tues.
Dear Jack:
This is primarily a thank you note - for the splendid time - and non-slimming food which you gave us happy guests last Saturday night.  Please thank Gladys.
I've just written The Reluctant Conscript - at Leonard Wood.  I told him the story of Brig. Gen Beauregard Lillard-Bond (CSA) - and put in a photo of the portrait.
I hope it will intrude a little on the idolatrous veneration of Bonus-Army MacArthur - Hoover's secret weapon.
Cordially
Joe Diggles

5/4/51
Dear Rev. C:
I think it's very fine our "Dad's" Treasurer has such tidy sums on him when he's robbed.
Goes to show not all of us Westerners are drinking booze!
Shall we start a "Relief" fund for brother Jules?
- soberly -
Joe Diggles
This poor slob has not heard the joyous word - "Dad's"!
- JCD.

[Newspaper clipping applicable to previous page:]
Loses $3,310 To Auto Bandit
Jules Klapman of 2924 North Shore av., treasurer of the Dad's Root Beer Co., told police he was robbed of $3,310 in cash and jewelry Thursday night when he returned to his car after attending a Loop movie.
Klapman said a robber, seated in the car parked on Washington st. near Wabash av., took $360 from his wallet, two rings worth $2,600, and a $350 wrist watch.

J. C. D.
HULL HOUSE
800 SO. HALSTED STREET
CHICAGO 7, ILLINOIS
7 May 1951
Dear Jack: In a world saddened by the news that South Africans would rather bait natives than fight Armed Slavs - quarrels between 5-Star generals and divorce amongst our "best" people - is it NOT enriching to know that the Business News Columns are playing up "Dads"?
I didn't even know we had "a fountain-flavor Division".  Is it one of those divisions guarding Formosa?
excitedly
- Rev. D.
- old soldier

[Newspaper clipping applicable to previous page:]
SUN TIMES
MONDAY, MAY 7, 1951
Business News In Brief
Robert L Moad has been appointed manager of the tabulating department in the Chicago office of Workman Service, Inc.  he formerly was with the Chicago & North Western Railroad and more recently in the sales department of International Business Machines.
W Scott Hassler has resigned as director of packing and assistant director of purchasing of the Curtiss Candy Co. to organize W. Scott Hassler Associates.  The new firm will specialize in package design and engineering service.

* *
Sale of the American Broadcasting Co. to the Columbia Broadcasting System is not under discussion at the present time, according to sources close to both networks.

* *
Lehman Bros., investment banking firm, has acquired 142,500 common shares of the National Supply Co., of which 117,000 shares are understood to represent holdings of the Pittsburgh Steel Co.

* *
Freight car deliveries to the nation's railroads during April increased 18 per cent above March as more steel was made available to builders, according to the Assn. of American Railroads and the American Railways Car Institute.

* *
Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., has entered into an agreement with Canada and the Ford Motor Co. of Canada, Ltd., under which the latter company will survey Canadian facilities for the production of the Willys Jeep.

* *
William H Russell has been named national sales manager of the fountain flavor division of Dad's Root Beer Co.  He formerly operated hos own advertising, marketing and merchandising agency.

Dear Jack:
[Text on back of postcard:]
Marker erected to mark the site of Stephen Fay's historic tavern, erected about 1769.  In the tavern Ethan Allen and his Green Mountain Boys used to gather.  The Council of Safety met there,  1777-1778.  The name "Catamount Tavern" was applies to it at a very late date.  The marker is not on the exact site of the tavern, the West front of which was forty-five feet East of the rear side of the marker.


It's clear that taverns and revolutions hatch each other.
O nasty fact!
AAly yrs
- Joe Diggles
Rev. Jack "Toots" Conroy
6012 S. Green St.
Chicago 21
Ill.

Algren, Gorman to Speak
Nelson Algren, author, and Judge Gibson E. Gorman of Narcotics Court will discuss the narcotics evil at the South Side Lodge of B'nai B'rith in the Shoreland Hotel Oct 24.

27 Oct 1951.
Dear Jack: With Labour licked in London - and Joe Louis washed up I feel quite down.
I am somewhat cheered by a flattering inscription in my copy of "Chicago - City on the Make" - from the author - Nelson "Big Monkey" Algren.
I enclose an AA report from Dublin, Ireland.  With Red Crayon I've encircled a lively bit of Irish history.
- bone dry -
Joe Diggles

Thank-U-Grams are Free... just as all the best things in life are.  The reverse side of this message shows how to obtain them.  Thank-U-Gram forms sent free anywhere in the world.

30 April 1952.
St Catherine of Siena
Dear Rev. "Toots" VIVA!
I enclose a letter from the sister of our old fellow-evangelist, Rob't Dowie Burrell.
It is clear Rob't is still alive - tho his final divorce between himself and Lady Barleycorn has not been issued.
I feel it would be in the interest of our reform movement if you'd drop Rev. B. a few heartening lines - and also enclose an NN tract or two - for I have a terrible fear that in his inhibitions and frustrations Rev. B. might possibly have turned to Luckies, Camels, Chesterfields or even Old Golds.
I note another minister is aiding Bob.  Send him a tract or 2 also.
Let us snatch the old oakenwald brand from further burning!
- always hope-ful for the Hop-full
- Joe Diggles
(AA) (NN)
P.S. Rob't Dowie Burrell
513 K. Street
Antioch, Calif.
Tell him of your great 6012 renovated mansion
- JCD

Built in 1891, the first building at St. Joseph's College.  Situated 80 miles from Chicago, St. Joseph's is a Catholic college with an enrollment of 500 men.  It is conducted by the Society of the Precious Blood.

Sheet II Page 1
COPY OF
Letter from Pearl Burrell - Bob's Mother - written 31 Dec '52
"Wednesday 31 Dec 1952
Dear Mary and Joe:
Your Xmas card came for Bob and I but Bob didn't get to see it.  He was killed on Now. 17 in an automobile accident.  He had taken me to Martinez to the hospital, I was to have an operation, he stayed till I was assigned to my room which was after lunch then he came home.  The minister came and talked to him.  I was expecting a package from Alma and I told him to open it.  The card was in the mail-box saying they had taken the package back.  He took his books back to the library and stopped and got the package and brought it home.  He opened it and there was a small radio in it.  he put it in the car and started back to the hospital to bring it to me.  As he reached the top of one of the hills the sun blinded him and he never saw the truck in front of him.  It was one of those large butane trucks, the driver said he looked back to see what happened and he saw Bob's car was steaming and went back to get Bob out in case the car caught on fire.  The man in back of Bon helped him to get out, they layed [sic] him on the grass beside of the road ->

but he was dead.  The front of the car was smashed and the steering wheel had cut the artery to his heart.  Alma came and got here Thursday night and the funeral was on Friday from the Congregational Church.  Bob had contacted that minister to help him with his problems and I became a member of it about a year ago.  Thank God the time is short when I will be called.
Love to you both.
Pearl"
Jack: be a good Joe - drop a note of condolence and pleasant recollections to
Mrs Pearl Burrell
513 K St.
Antioch, Ill
- one of the surviving 2 of the Oakland-Kenwood tractemans
- Joe. D.

5 Sept, 1953.
Saturday.
Dear Jack: VIVA!
My Hammond's atlas tells me 1715 wretches endure Arkansas life in the town of Lonoke - where the enclosed AA paper comes forth every 2 weeks.
Imagine living in Lonoke!  Imagine living sober in Lonoke!!  Such courage!
Baxter Miles (the editor) is my new "hero" - to supplant my former one, Douglas MacArthur.
Since weather stopped your invasion of Arkansas maybe this brave AA paper will wing you there in spirit.
Yr fellow reformer,
Joe Diggles.

8 Nov. 1953
Sunday
Dear fellow-liberator: VIVA!
Let me tell you that Mary and I concur in the opinion that your 60 souls, 2-generations blow-out was the gayest event we've been to in the entire reign of Elizabeth !!.
"These wild geese shall never meet again!"
Tell Jack and Gladys that we are very grateful to have been on the guest list.  Had it not been for our advanced years we would have stayed for breakfast - as I fear many may have done!
The enclosed AA booklet from Australia is to help you in your reform work in Oregon.  I've heard the Northwest Harvest is great - the gleaners few and far between.  Let uncle Charlie read it first if he wishes to.
Thanks again, Jack -
ciglessly yours -
Joe Diggles

I wonder if we could get this "pink" Bishop to go over to "Bussell" in honor of the late Robert Dowie Bussell, our fellow - Reformer?
With Bodenheim & Battling Nelson both dead in the same "Sun-times" I am stricken.
Tell Gladys to STOP SMOKING"!!!

P.S. Let's go see Recluse Nelson - the Hoosier existentialist!
With an author like Bodenheim killed - be careful, Courey. The Rumor could get about that you are stashing $100 Bills in every book in your library - and you too could know the fate of Julius Caesar - or Bodenheim. May persons I know would be interested in books under No other sort of inducement!
Agless in the City smog - Joe D

"This day be grateful homage paid, and loud hosannas sung;  Let gladness dwell in every heart, and praise on every tongue."
Since April 9 is the 89th ann. of the surrender of R.E. Lee to that filthy Trotskyite U.S. Grant gen. Beauregard and I go into mourning on that date of ignominy.
Thank goodness for April 8th away the Bowl! - and April 9th!
ex/PfC -
Joe Diggles.
